review_title: Honeywell Review for Philippines Shared Services for HR ADMIN LEARNING HELP HRS Services
pros:
Encourage to share best practices
Promotion, if and only "sipsip" you can be.
cons:
1. High attrition because of  Micromanaging, specially with team leaders. 

  A. You need to report every move. Where you are these and that.
B.  OT is big deal and are not encourage. Then add manpower as solution.

2. Politics - observable you can tell 1st to 2 weeks 
3.  ANNUAL SALARY INCREASE has poor explanation on Performance Score
they have this 9 block rating where at first may soundly fair because of behaviors and perfomance scores have been combined  but supervisors are very poor in explaining the corresponding rating. 

Safe answers and scripted as you can imagine how it can be like lines : 

"you can do better with your ratings if you do this and that but whenever being asked the basis are vague".

Interesting part is for the increase.
"..and this is the corresponding increase for your rating, we have a tool that recommends your increase" ( so where and how the 9block can be integrated if they have this tool, subjective isn't it?)

Tls are claiming reviews are back and forth.  Other companies would normally submit as it is that verification from the upper mgt.

3.  Lots of adhoc that do not contribute to individuals growth instead it adds on the pressure aside from the KPI you have.
Many unneccessary tasks. You need to MANUALLY PUNCH IN your meetings you can imagine that the management dont trust you. They say to this needs to be done measure the manpower needs but c'mon its been a year. Tls will remind you now and then, you shouldnt  forget to ENCODE your adhocs in the tracker.
 
Tips: Then, better if you purchase a time in motion tool to capture whatever your employees are doing. 

4.  Trainings - they promote people but do not have time to invest with the necessary skills  training set to impart those who've been promoted. At least an essential one, basics like 
1.  Leadership Development Programs
2.  People Management / People handling

For normal people like us, training are ONLY VISUAL boring.  No time for room trainings 

5. Office gossips - pioneers are the initiator and mock leadership team

cons: Departments can be lean with high expectations of employees. Demands, workload, and pressure can be very high at time. This is common across many functions. Recommended for those that enjoy learning and a challenge.

review_title: Not a bad place to work, but work ethics are sometimes replaced with BS
pros:
Technical abilities and over all education of peers is top tier
Career growth and opportunity
cons:
Processes can make for difficult challenges to achieving objectives
Too much management, too little workers. 
Risk is not rewarded or supported.

review_title: HW is a big company that buys the little guy then promptly disasembles thems or send their jobs to China
pros: The pay is decent if you are willing to relocate to whereever they want you to.
cons: Bennifits are crappy and very expensive to boot.

review_title: Internship . took a while to pay off, but its on the good part now.
pros: Good pay. Good thing to have on a resume.
cons: they had me mostly doing testing. and not even the interesting testing, but just user acceptance testing... BORING. also they'll make the job description sound like its as coding-intense as any other internship, and there IS SOME small coding, but hardly any.

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Rockford, IL
pros: None. except for people I work with.
cons: terrible pay raises along with no paid overtime. Health insurance keeps getting worse. I stopped paying for HW health benefits. no training in many years that I have been here. Learn as you go.

Pace is unrealistic and introduces too many errors.
HTSI has the habit of over engineering EVERYTHING.
Lean Six Sigma is simply given lip service, no real effort to institute.

review_title: Growth opportunities are present for those who add real value.
pros: Honeywell is a stable organization that has been able to weather the downturn effectively by being positioned well in good industries.
cons: As the economy has continued to struggle along, many are now expected to do much more with less.

review_title: Growth opportunities are present for those who add real value.
pros: Honeywell is a stable organization that has been able to weather the downturn effectively by being positioned well in good industries.
cons: As the economy has continued to struggle along, many are now expected to do much more with less.

review_title: Moving away from deep Engineering and into Systems engineering
pros: Interesting product line that was cutting edge.
cons: Bought pieces from suppliers and engineered the 'bolt' that put them together.  And they didn't even do that correctly.  Too many layers of management and at times it can be tough dealing with their foreign workers.

pros: The benefit package is above average.  They treat all levels of employees the same.  The leadership ensures all people are kept in the loop with the most updated information.
cons: HR department unwilling to go to bat for mid-level managers.  Progression is limited to one pay step per year.  Ensure the ability to progress to the desired positions.

pros: Big name in the marketplace - everyone knows Honeywell.  It's a stable company, has a variety of businesses to find your niche, and they offer decent benefits.
cons: Even though there are females in senior leadership, the culture at Honeywell is very much a "boy's club".

job_title: Human Resources Lead in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good learning & development opportunities. Great Go-To-Market strategy. Really like the people I worked with.
cons: Very little - sometimes the performance management process became the objective in itself. They sit on huge amounts of valuable people data but can't translate it into smart people actions.

review_title: I'm still here but NO room for advancement..
pros: Been with the company from the Allied Signal days --which were the best. Have possibly too much to lose (retirement) if I leave now, otherwise I would be gone.
cons: If you are a minority, you're not going anywhere I've realized. Good old boy system still alive and well here. The insurance is the WORST I've ever seen or heard of for manufacturing jobs.

pros: Work environment is not very stressful and mostly you can choose your own projects.
cons: Growth opportunities are very limited, very perception based culture, decision making is extremely slow.

review_title: I have 13 years of experience in power supply design and reliability engineering.
pros: it s very good company with very nice work environment. but I want onsite opportunity for similar kind of work for international exposure.
cons: getting onsite opportunity and growth is a big challenge in this  time period where its very important for betterment.

pros: One of the biggest pros to the company is company match 401k and pension.

review_title: Ok for a starter.  However salary is not on par as you become old in the organisation joined as a fresher

Excellent pay
Flexible hours within engineering
Professional atmosphere

Great people with years of experience

pros:
Great place to work.

Lot of learning in terms of managing time, dealing with people as well as technically.
cons:
Legendary applications still use old technology, need to compete with market.
Getting access to new tools of trending technology. there is a initiative on this.

pros: Great employment opportunity at any time during your career. College graduate or seasoned professional. Diverse and challenging atmosphere with opportunities for growth.
cons: Globally focused company which can be challenging for someone just starting their career.  Patience and consistent application of effort is the key.

review_title: Only Aero And ACS department is good. DONT JOIN ITSS
pros: brand name, learning, job security. Aero and ACS are good department.
cons: very bad appraisal in ITSS department. You can say ITSS is support department of Aero and ACS. Bad work life balance. Micro management in most of the teams.

pros: Great people to work with. Most people are generous in sharing their expertise and answering questions. Welcoming and open environment.
cons: Some methodologies need modernization. New software technologies can help make workflow efficiency improve, but change and adoption of new tools seem to be slow.

pros: During the 2008 financial crisis, Honeywell worked very hard to keep everyone. To do this we had to take a week of unpaid vacation. That, I think was a very courageous and caring thing to do.
cons: A little heavy with the administrative daily time card tracking and stop work states related to contractual obligations. But unavoidable due to government contract rules

pros: Solid company with great product portfolio.  Some really great people who strive to do the right thing.  Good opportunities for advancement if you align to the company path.
cons: Narrow functional focus reinforced by compensation plans which prevents efficiencies across groups.  Lack of recognition of the importance of IT to the success of the organization as digital transformation engulfs industries.

pros: There are opportunities to move around since it's such a big company. The pay is good and the products are interesting.
cons: The programs are intense because the resources are constrained. There are layoffs and furloughs happening often.

job_title: Principal Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good, talented people to work with.  Most willing to help someone if they ask, and dedicated to making their job a success.  Good safety record.
cons: Benefits are continuously being reduced.  Layoffs and random unpaid week long furloughs occur, even as the company spends $2.5 B buying up other companies, spends $1.9B buying up their own stock, and boosting stock dividends 12%.  Workers receive raises about once every two years.  Lots of unpaid overtime.  Few promotions.

job_title: Electronic Security Systems Technician in Yuma, AZ
pros: Excellent at recognizing talent and staffing like techs across diverse locations. Benefits, trustworthiness and decent raises. Solid hietory of performance.
cons: Political at times. Lot of alcoholics it seems. Good old boy network. Too much paperwork and training. More work time less web crap to fill out.

review_title: 4 years of Experience in Process Automation

There is a balance between office and personal life. 
Lots of onsite opportunities to different countries.
cons: There are not much of the cons to discuss. Only con which I see is being a Process Automation you need to work on both Hardware and Software.

review_title: Decent Place to work at with a few concerns

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Plaines, IL
pros: UOP was a great company to work for until the big H took over in 2006.

pros: Most people have heard the name, even if they don't know what sort of products or services are offered, therefore it looks better on a resume than less well known companies.
cons:
1) Corporate greed runs rampant. One week they are sharing news of how well the company did last quarter and what great profits they had, and the next week they are sending out internal memos about spending and travel freezes so that we can perform to what the shareholders were promised. They always put the shareholders first, even when the actions to do so will negatively impact customers (many of the decrees are very short sighted). Customers come second and employees place last by a long shot. 

2) Honeywell buys well performing companies, takes their customer base, their IP, their suppliers, and anything else they can gut, and then outsources to the foreign country flavor of the month. If you work for a US based company that is bought by Honeywell, expect to see your job outsourced to China, Mexico, or India within 1-2 years. The outsourcing announcement was officially made at my company at the 1.5 yr mark, but the original plan began circling in upper levels of management around the 6 month mark, which is a pretty good indication that outsourcing was the plan from day 1. 

3) Honeywell is a "check the box" company. It does not matter if your actions produced valuable results, as much as it matters that you can say you did what the job required. On a regular basis, I see employees and leadership going through the motions to check the box, but not even caring about the outcome.

4) Honeywell is so big that it is very common that the left hand does not know what the right hand is doing. It is pretty much a daily occurrence in some meeting or another.

5) Honeywell invests massively into "High Growth Regions", which includes countries like China, India, and pretty much any country where employees are paid dirt. Yet, they have no respect for the American lives that they screw up when they lay off long-term employees in order to show headcount reductions. 

6) Top management makes millions of dollars per year, and yet the company "struggles" to do well in a tight economy, so it is most important that employees understand when the blue-collar and no-collar jobs need to be cut in order for the company to look good to investors.

review_title: Once a great place before Honeywell bought it!
pros: Co-workers a great group of people to work with! Most of those on the floor really want to put out great products. Mostly safe work enviroment. Some leadership doing their best to make things better.
cons:
Honeywell Operating System (HOS) too much a burden to product developement and production fixing things that aren't broken. Too much emphasis on metrics (which are changed often) rather than the actual work that needs to be done. Production schedules are very unrealistic and do not take into account design flaws not anticipated before hitting the assembly floor. Some managers care about those that actually do the work while others (and supervisors) only care about "making numbers" to satisfy those above them. Corporate management pretends to care about employee welfare but don't show it in practice. Benefits reduced yearly and fair raises and bonuses non-existent. Way too many wasteful meetings throughout the plant for minor issues that result in little or no solutions! Too many of those in the meetings could solve most of the problems if they'd just spend more time on the floor. The ones at the lowest levels doing all the work (sacrificing home life) are not fairly compensated. Overall....the work enviroment is not a happy one, moralel there has dropped dramatically since the Honeywell take-over, and unless some drastic changes are made soon it'll only get worse. 

Personally, I wish I could have had a more positive time with Honeywell but could not take the all the negative changes I was seeing, chose to leave for my own sanity! If you have any self worth and want to enjoy your chosen career consider other companies before signing on with this one!

review_title: Worst Job I've Ever Had or Even Heard Of
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sarasota, FL
pros:
- You get a regular paycheck.
- Sarasota, FL is a beautiful, peaceful city.
- If you hate to learn new technologies or the latest software engineering methodologies, this is the place for you. With few exceptions, the culture at this site is to try to keep the state of software development like it was 20 years ago. This is because the current staff has little interest in learning new skills.
- If you are looking to manufacture a situation where you can sue the company for which you work, there is a decent chance of achieving that here. Some managers constantly make really inappropriate comments.
- You want to work somewhere that you can pretty much do what you want with impunity and no fear of getting fired. You may get laid off some day though. See my Layoffs comment under Cons.
- Unless you’re involved in one of the many “fires”, you are pretty much left alone to perform your task. This is opposed to some places that micromanage you and want to know how far along you are every few hours.
- Despite the fact that management refuses to do what it takes to correct the site’s issues or even accept that many of the issues exist, they seem to have a desire to correct the site’s issues.
cons:
- This is not a software engineering position. This is a programming position. Sadly, the unqualified employees don’t seem to know the difference between the two.
- Forget about promotion at this site, it is a dead end job. Due to a product that has been constantly losing millions every year, there is no budget for anything here. I've had to purchase my own office supplies.
- No one learns from the past. Problems that threaten the product are never solved and you always encounter the same problems. 
- Due to decades of lay offs and people quitting, many of the longtime employees appear to have gotten positions for which they are not qualified. The result is an atmosphere where employees are solely concentrating on covering themselves, which means lots of announcing/highlighting another’s mistakes and lots of bragging about their own accomplishments.
- No understanding of the term “work/life balance”. The culture here is that you are willing to work 24/7, you’re on-call, and willing to give up your vacations for the company. The worst part is that the job ad and the information you get in the interview is that you will just need to put in a little of over-time around deadlines. The reality is far worse. Managers have actually stated (this is an exact quote): “I don’t care about people’s weekends or vacations.” In addition, as an engineer, you are expected to work at least a consistent 50 hours a week, even if you’re getting pay for only 40 hours a week. This is all a result of too much work versus the available manpower.
- Most of the programming work is done overseas. One thing this means is that you can expect the core of your job to be putting out the “fire of the day”. With whatever time you have left, you can then do some real programming. However, most of the good portions of software will be done overseas. This also means you’ll need to get up early for those meetings with the overseas team.
- Ridiculous deadlines. Take however long you think a software package will take, then divide that by three and that’s your deadline. And it’ll be expected you work nights, weekends, and delay vacation to make the deadline. Try to be clever and extend your estimate by a factor of three and managers will just submit a much lower estimate and then they’ll divide that by three.
-  Many employees and managers are condescending, unhelpful, and incompetent. The few competent employees seem to be constantly needing to work around the other employees. The general rule at this site is to help yourself first, and then if you have time, continue helping yourself, because other people don’t matter.
-  There seems to be a hire/layoff cycle here. Every few years there’s another layoff after building up the number of employees.
- There is a culture of “you’ll do what we tell you”. Forget about what they tell you in the job ad or the interview. As an employee at this site, it’s expected you’ll do whatever management says. If they need you to travel overseas, clean out some dark, forgotten, dust-buried corner of the site, or just work 100 hours a week, you’re expected to do it, regardless of whether or not it’s in your job description, part of your compensation package, or have a good reason for not being able to do it. Certainly, there are many small companies that expect you to “wear many hats”, but they usually state this at some point before you get hired. At this site, not only will they not mention it, they will be surprised when you explain to them that it needed to be mentioned.
- Attention from management is used as a motivator. Most employees here are afraid of management, and many in management seem to encourage this view. This results in attention being used as a motivator during “fires”.
- Most management openly do not care about their employees. Managers have actually said “I don’t care” toward their employee's special family events. Certainly, at the very least, there are better ways to respond to an employee in that situation.
- No where to get information for your task. The only time you can get information on your task is when it is due. There is a “just figure it out” attitude here. Then, when it’s due, employees will seemingly come out of no where to give you a list of things you’re software package should do, but doesn’t. As a result, there’s a lot of software here that does not work like it should. Rewrites happen more often than it should
- Management seems to enjoy lateness. Management will act extremely slow in making decisions in a project until very late in the life-cycle, only to result in a “Herculean effort” to get the project done. It’s not clear if management enjoys the adrenaline rush of being late, or fears making decisions.
- No tools. The system you work on can be described as a complex, distributed system. As such, you really need tools to troubleshoot it. Not only are there very few tools (and those tools are poor), there is not even any recognition of a need for tools. If you want to work quickly and efficiently via great tools, be prepared to not only make your own tools, but to do it on your own time. 
- Very little praise for anything you do. At this site, software engineers are not looked at as part of the solution, we are part of the problem. Since management has very little understanding of software, and even less interest in attempting to understand software, software is looked at as something easy and quick to complete. 
- Multiple people seem intent on driving the site into a direction of their own choosing, aka have their own agendas. This results in people going behind you to sabotage your efforts if they don’t agree with them.  
- To stay at this position, you’ll need to learn to love frustration. Frustration seems quite consistent among most employees. It's just extremely difficult to get anything done and meanwhile there are strict deadlines.

job_title: Project Specialist III in Houston, TX
pros:
Flexible work hours. My star ratings are an average of my immediate situation of the last few years, my situation the decade before that, and what I see going on among all the people with whom I work.
My immediate manager is an amazing anomaly, constantly pushing us to move up the ladder, explaining the boxes that need to be checked off so upper management can't block our promotions and how to navigate the god-awful politics and get around the massive road block that is "HR", the Lawsuit Prevention Squad. Upper management would get rid of him if they knew what he was doing for us as it goes against the one and only commandment of "Thou Shalt Cut Costs At All Cost!." None of the other managers I have had in the last 15 years had the stones to even try to explain what it really takes to get promoted in this environment. Just promote the ones you like. Most didn't even understand our group's true function, and considered all of us unpromotable because 'you only do ...' My present manager is the only reason I could give anything 2 stars.
cons: Where to start...don't be fooled, darius is dave's clone without a personality (which can be pos or neg depending on your point of view). Other than the very small  bubble I am currently in, what I see going on around me is appalling. The last 5-6 years have been a rapidly accelerating descent through chaos into indifference.  Read the other reviews for details, what they describe is spot on. Don't be fooled by the company sponsored 4-5 star 1-2 sentence reviews that are probably required in bulk of HR minions so they can be promoted. The best employees are loaded up to the point of collapse/quitting as they try to keep things afloat with no support from their managers, the best of whom are also overloaded and completely hamstrung by upper management's greed for ever larger bonuses. The company is being hollowed out by upper management skimming off the top while the employees doing the work get less and less for their efforts. When management states there is 'really no way to measure customer satisfaction' you are forced to realize just how deep the hole you are in really is. And in spite of everything they won't stop digging; they dig faster and harder.

review_title: Engineering / Marketing - Instability, Low Morale, Declining Reputation
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Golden Valley, MN
pros:
Generally I had great co-workers (a few bad ones too), but everyone is frustrated with the work environment and searching for another job.
Flexible work schedules and ability to work remote (although both of these are being phased-out).
401k match is nice, but fairly average for the industry.
cons:
Honeywell used to be a great company, but it all changed after the merger with Allied Signal in 1999.
Work environment is completely unstable (in the past year there were 2 major re-orgs and 5 layoffs).  There is actually a large department at corporate that is dedicated to processing layoffs and there have been so many layoffs that there are not enough people to deliver product to the customer (there are major product quality issues and most products are delivered late).
Low pay scales, no merit pay raises (for the past 6 years), no bonus pay (for the past 2 years), annual pay cuts (typically 10%), and horrible benefits (high premiums; dental benefits completely cut).
Low morale due to continuous layoffs, horrible management, and poor financial metrics (employees don't understand how the company reports record growth/profits to investors, but internally employees hear that revenue is down across all divisions).
Management lacks integrity, ethics, and accountability (corporate lawyers make decisions based on "We don't think we will get caught").  There are major violations of federal law that could potentially bar the company from business.
Very few opportunities for employee training or career development.  No career advancement opportunities.
"Honeywell Operating System" (HOS) is ridiculous - it is simply standard work that the company should already do.
Declining company reputation makes it extremely difficult to recruit talent.  I had several open reqs and only ~10 applicants over 6 months for each one; every applicant asked me about the company's poor reviews and reputation.

review_title: The worst possible company to work for in NJ (Morris Plains)
job_title: Director, Product Management in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: Difficult to think of something. Salary is slightly above average but NJ taxes make sure you are not left any better. You do get free coffee and some Kool aid. Plenty of red tape from every department. Cold shoulder and lack of support from IT and HR. If you are researching workplace abuse and how US citizens are subservient to foreigners, this is probably a good spot to spend some time.
cons: Pretty much everything. As soon as you join, you are on your own. No one responds to your questions with useful information, there are no documents anywhere, no processes. If you are an SBG employee or corporate, its worse, everyone in the SBU's and GBE's hate you and want you to fail. Worse still the SBU's and GBE's have all the information you need for your job and are located all over the world in different time zones. For goals, you are essentially given pie in the sky targets like grow revenue by 5%, margin by 3% etc. Of course you have no authority to change anything nor are you given a team. A title and a laptop are all that you have. Next is your boss, most likely a foreigner or someone from management consulting. If its a foreigner, he is most likely a racist that has never faced an employment lawsuit for abuse. Get ready to be yelled at, cursed at, told you know nothing and get abused for your e-mails not being grammatically correct. You can't impress your boss with any accomplishments, all he cares about are power point presentations. He will use your presentations to look good in front of his boss. You will not have access to any data or systems, trying to get access will send you in a loop to India and back to the US with no result. Forget all your skills learnt previously, they are useless. Everything revolves around meetings and presentations. You are expected to know things about every business automatically. Every meeting feels like a quiz where you are asked detailed questions about some business process on some line of business in Europe. You will not know the answer and your boss won't either, but he will expect you to find out. Unfortunately no one in Europe will respond to you with information, or will send you some canned nonsense.I can go on and on, but its better to do the smart thing and jump ship like so many have done in 2019

review_title: Corporate culture including management-employees interaction is completely communist style driven.
pros: There are no "pro" reasons to work at Honeywell, a company engaged in self-sabotage for the benefit of a communist style elite, committed to maximize their gains at the expense of the company.
cons: The multi-layered management is heavily trained and structured in a iron-clad reporting network functioning with the same grassroots philosophy as the one perfected by the organized crime organizations. There is a gigantic and impenetrable Iron Curtain between management and employees. There is no one to go to and adddress concerns as an employee, since management/HR are committed to the vow of absolute blind bonding amonst themselves and against the fellow employees.  The annual reviews are blatant mockeries. Managers are delivering their "evaluations" based on bogus assessments and claims, knowingly so, affording a sarcastic hideous smile while delivering your "development in place" plan for the next period. No performance review complaint has been ever resolved, indifferent of how strong was the evidence presented to support such claim. Illustrous is the case of an employee reveiving the exceptional assessment "Exceeds Honeywell Standards" from the Program Manager he worked for the entirely complete year, and yet the Manager responsible for this employee's annual performance review, downgraded him to "Below Honeywell Standards", requiring his inductance in a Performance Improvement Plan for the next year. Mind bending!

pros:
Low Emotional Mental and Intellectual Energy Company. 

They are good at being super cheap. They manage to the order of 20 cents. Great company for cheap employees working in a cheap environment. 

They try to indirectly force employees from different facilities against each other. Great place to learn how to be a TOXIC LEADER and TOXIC MANAGER. It will teach you the dark arts of creating a toxic environment. Great place to develop neither EFFICIENCY NOR CREATIVITY. I am making this place my scientific project to determine what this environment breeds.

No growth but a good place to warm your chair for 10+ years in one position and then hop to the adjacent cubicle for another 10+ years if you are that type with no ambitions.

They have outsourced their relocation services to cheap companies like SIRVA which handles the supposedly difficult conversations since Honeywell's advice to them is to discourage by every means necessary to provide any benefits to the employee.

You will learn to be a SLAVE in this Company by the time they are done with you. You will seek neither COIN, FAME, POSITION, SUCCESS OR POWER in this firm but end up losing it after selling your rights and privileges. In the end, you can look at your reflection and gleam at the HOPELESS CREATURE that you have become! 

Mark my words!

They have one thing Right. That is the work life balance and FLEXTIME! I will praise Honeywell with no Honey in its well for this privilege.
cons:
1) Facilities are old, worn and broken. 
2) Building are actually trailers. It is a trailer park in the Phoenix facility.
3) Harmful and toxic emissions that are inhaled in this facility. Management simply avoids the topic and avoids cleaning up the junk.
4) Employees are given desks and chairs that are over 30 years old. They are broken and quite some of them got hurt.
5) Management does a scavenger hunt around the junkyard, dumpsters and trash collection points to find cables, cords, chairs, desks, materials etc.
6) Even Senior managers are placed in cubicles and expected to share it with other team members in some occasions. Even they use dumpster chairs.
7) The building is packed like sardines.
8) Facilities need serious attention and overhaul. Most of them don't even meet the fire code and building safety codes. It looks like old mud hills from the 1960s
9) There is barely any young person in this facility who retain their position for more than 6 months.
10) The senior professionals with over 27 years of service are simply waiting anxiously to get their pension and 401(k).
11) Most managers due to depression have a lackluster performance because they are asked to manage with a shoestring budget. 
12) They are audited for buying paper, pen, paper clips, power cords and anything over $20.
13) I think the Company is politely telling everyone to leave the facility so that they can covertly discourage libels, lawsuits and severance pay for many of these professionals.
14) Zero accountability from Senior Leadership. I mean absolute ZERO besides empty speeches and hollow promises that are expected to deliver no outcome. They rarely visit the plant, facilities to determine the health, safety and environment of the employees.
15) All the neighboring industrial zones have been marked for restoration. In fact all the neighboring industries have had their buildings demolished.
16) Going to work is an absolutely DEMORALIZING and UNHEALTHY EXPERIENCE.

review_title: Don't work here, it's not worth it.
pros: The engineers are dedicated and some of the best people I've worked with in the ACS//ISC/Aerospace business. Very smart and overall a pleasure to work with. The 401K match is decent,but only if you put away 7% of your paycheck towards it. Pay is decent, however a good chunk of it is taken up by the ridiculous healthcare costs.
cons:
The benefits are a joke- the healthcare is astronomically expensive and there's no company match.
It takes years before you get any additional vacation time added (5 years until you get an additional week) and you never get additional PTO. 
The work/ life balance at Honeywell is deplorable and that's attributed to the austerity measures put in by the top brass (CEO - Cote) a couple years ago, plus bad planning all the way down the leadership chain - in all business units. Simply put, if you work here you're just a number; a metric, not a person with a life outside Honeywell. And this company will work you until they either break you or lay you off. There are better and more stable engineering companies out there.
Very little development or promotional opportunities unless you're in the senior, upper leadership. I rarely see regular engineers/ managers promoted to the next level in any SBU.
Honeywell is a very bloated company. There are metrics and more metrics and so many processes we have to go through to get simple things done (ordering software, refreshing computers, office supplies, etc) that we waste a lot of our time just trying to accomplish basic tasks when we could be doing science.

pros: None that I can think of.
cons: There are absolutely no perks to working for this company.  Many people that work there, you can see it in their eyes that they died  inside a long time ago and are just going through the daily motions. The building is old and decrepit, and in a small, difficult to get to town in Southern Germany. If you spend more than 10 Euros a day on food while travelling, you will get asked by your manager to explain yourself. The company is INCREDIBLY cheap when it comes to travel. If you take a taxi somewhere, i.e. to get dinner, etc, expect to have to explain yourself to an angry manager yelling at you for "wasting the company's money".   Management initially expected me to drive 5 hours starting at 4am, so I could be at a day long meeting at 9am to save the cost of a night at a hotel. I refused.  Management is also extremely micro-managerial.  Even when you are in training and not doing much in the way of actually dealing with accounts or visiting clients or talking to anyone yet, expect to have to send multiple daily fluff emails to your manager to keep them satisfied.  Also, the training is TERRIBLE. I was a sales account manager, and the training I was given was days long, and designed for an installation technician, not a member of the sales team. It was absolutely useless and covered nothing about value proposition, the competition, features, benefits, etc. You know, the useful stuff a sales person might need to know in order to sell a product. It seemed like they really had no plan and no direct sales experience.  There was also no lead generation mechanism, or Business development department. You are expected to cold call giant international Fortune 500 corporations...in Germany.  Good luck with that!  2 weeks into working for Honeywell, I already hated it and regretted accepting their offer. 4 weeks into it, I had already made up my mind to quit and started sending out new resumes, and by week 6, before I had even gotten my ears wet, and just as I was finishing "training", I simply couldn't take it any more.  Other members of my team ( who started when I did, and who I became good friends with) had similar misgivings. Time will tell how long they'll last there. I suspect not very long. I have NEVER worked at a company that I hated so much, so quickly. This was the shortest job I ever had and it felt like a piano had been lifted off my shoulder when I left. Honeyhell is a giant, soul sucking bureaucratic, American corporate hellscape.

job_title: Advanced Systems Engineer in Aguadilla, PR
pros: In my 1st year I received an award as Honeywell Outstanding Engineer, accomplish that is not easy to achieve when you are compare with the hard work of other talent coworkers.  The company provide opportunities grow professionally and meet new places to work.
cons: Personally, I don't have downsides because I changed my previous job of 16 years. The key of your satisfaction is during the interview negotiation.

pros: Golden legacy, customers loved UOP, a long-standing technical reputation of invention and innovation, some very good and knowledgeable people
cons:
Every day starts with a veiled threat to your job - in some way or the other.....saying DO THIS or THE BIG BOSS IS WATCHING....!!!!! and you will be evicted...

A company crushed under mighty Honeywell Greed, (a fancy MANTRA.... Value Capture)........how to squeeze the last drop from the employee and customer is the name of the game. The management 'flavor of the day, everyday' is to take away from the employee.........so that the stock market returns the favor to the 'management' in terms of stock price. 

Company culture is ABSENT. A 100 hundred year old company, completely devoid of its 'individual culture'.

Everything moving, talking or breathing is a cost.....so needs reduction.... under the garb of 'maximize value for the inventor'.

Very bad management, timid leadership. John Gugel restructured the company twice within a span of 6 months with no clarity and completely jargon filled messaging. 

Rajeev Gautam (although equally to be blamed) is not UOP president anymore.... he is in the larger Honeywell group PMT, wherein UOP sits. 

Honeywell simply believes in Hiring and Firing. No regard for Technical competence, expertise, loyalty, track-record or experience. 

You need to be a YES (WO)/Man. Middle management seems toothless and powerless......the grape wine is that it seems they need 'permissions' for breathing also.

Senior leadership seems absolutely clueless......they just seem to parrot words fed to them by Honeywell Top leadership. every message has to have the name of the Honeywell CEO mentioned........to 'enforce' action. 

Most of the VP'S have no operational understanding or experience of the businesses they are running..... have arrived for their corporate honeymoon with pre-listed cost-cutting objectives, from parent Honeywell. 

An entire team of wishful thinkers is sitting in the HO spinning webs of stories (that Honeywell likes to listen to) without engaging with the ground. ear to the ground is MUTED- your opinion is 'rubbish' if it does not align with the top. 

No one wants to hear a 'NO'. it seems that even the customer is not allowed to say 'NO'- however genuine their concern.
 
The company has, over last 7 years seen a very profitable run, with every year seeing a record of sorts...... in spite of this, raises are minimal or none followed by repeated rounds of LAY-OFFS and Furloughs 'enforced' to please the ''INVESTOR''.

review_title: Not a good place to work.
pros:
Very few. The name used to look good on a resume but is being rapdily eroded by poor management. Allied Signal bought Honeywell in order to buy the reputation and has steadily dragged Honewyell down to the level of Allied Signal. Whatever you used to read that was bad about Allied Signal, is now what applies to Honeywell.
Still acknowledged as an industry leader in some areas, but lack of new products is bringing that reputation down.
cons:
Used to be technology and inovation leader., but is now a very poor also ran. Investment decisions have diverted money away from real product development. Honeywell now exists by buying other companies and stripping them.

Honeywell's best engineers now work for a company started by former Honeywell employees. That company has taken Honewyell's 90% market share, has taken most of Honeywell's engineers and is now THE leading supplier in the market segment.

Absolutely zero opportuities for advancement. I have been told on 3 separate occassions that I would not be considered for a job in the US because tHonewyell was not prepared to bring someone from offshore

Performance reviews and recognition are a very poor joke. I have been personally told that senior management downgraded the review given by my manager, in order to meet a quota and avoid giving me a pay increase

Salaries have been frozen for 3 years

We took a mandated pay cut this year but managers still expected us to work the same overtime and weekend hours over and above a 40 hour week.

They have forgotten how to look after the cusomers. 4 years ago I had a travel budget of $125,000 to visit the customers and resolve their problems. My budget this year, to do the same job, is $12,000.

Managers are fascinated with surveys, and use them to get the ratings they want, rather than recognizing the genuine customer concerns expressed in surveys. I have personally had managers tell me that they ignored certain well respected industry surveys becasue they were negative.

Downsizing has been the constant theme since the Allied Signal acquisition.

Gives lip service to training but in reality does not provide it. I have had to go troubleshoot completely new systems with zero product training prior to seeing the system on the aircraft.

Management philosophy is to try to imitate GE. They have not succeeded.

Over the last ten years I have watched a $300M business unit become a $30M business unit, while the stock price has been protected by cost cutting. There is nothing left for the future.

job_title: Industrial Design Lead in Chicago, IL
pros: Design is new for Honeywell (the CEO made a statement about wanting Honeywell to be 'the Apple of Industrials' so there is a lot to do there. Honeywell essentially buys smaller companies and lets them run, so as a designer you can step in and help them build better products and experiences.
cons:
The industrial design management is horrific and created a toxic work environment. ID management's style is essentially a bat about the head and neck. ID management uses verbal abuse as the primary management tool, followed up by tirades and berating language. ID management lies about what is expected from you, making things like deliverables change from day to day. ID management has unrealistic and hidden expectations about how design and designers should work, and uses that against the designers. ID management takes no responsibility for anything as far as I could tell.
Here is an example: I met ID management at one of the Honeywell subsidiaries in the  suburbs of a major midwestern city for a kick off meeting around designing new fire control systems. This is a typical product development meeting, where the designers meet with engineers to understand technical limitations (manufacturing electronics etc) and meet with product management, who own the business side of the products (what it needs to do, and cost and who its for). These meetings are what they sound like, a kick off- a chance to meet your product development partners and get on the same page. Designers typically leave these meetings and put plans to gather for the project; schedule, process resources etc.
I walked into this facility and ID management pulled me aside immediately into an empty office and began dressing me down about why I had not brought a presentation to show these people. I was horrified that I had missed this assignment and had no idea what ID management was referring to- it was a kick off meeting, we were there to learn.  Then it became apparent this was one more wacky mind game. As I caught myself I realized no one even asked me if I had a presentation, ID management just laid into me for NOT having a presentation.
That is the type of mind games I constantly endured at Honeywell, and the type of behavior Honeywell believes makes them successful.
 As a designer please stay away. It is a stifling and crushing creative environment. ID management is doing nothing that remotely looks like it's heading Honeywell toward the 'Apple of the Industrials'.
In short its the worst job I have EVER had in my life. And I have had some lame jobs.

cons:
We can write a book with regards to cons.
1. Management and their stupid policies
2. Hr dept and IT dept way of work with no use

6. Salary hikes - you need not to ask about this, when the management is only worried about cost savings and productivity savings , they don't even bother if you ask also. When you do it's the high time for an individual to look outside before they terminates you by deploying unnecessary reasons.
7. Never ever work under Aerospace business segment, as there are old stupid people sitting in the management who never be in a position to change or adopt to new technologies or never listen to employees problems.

Especially in PSE (Product support engineering) and C&PS ( customer and product support)  , don't ask their working principles. As they are the most useless and stupid policies they follow.
7. Never ever think about fun activities or any kind of outing, as you would be questioned on the business targets and progress and you actually land up in having productivity savings that they use for those activities.
PSE function don't like to spend INR 252 rs. from business fund for snacks for any of the fun event and ask the management on cost revision for that financial year.
8. Don't think about the individual growth as the management is only worried about monthly and yearly goals and how to achieve those Savings by setting the high targets which are impossible to achieve.
9. You feel like working in a kingdom type or in a school. Every manager thinks that they are dictators and deploy business strategies and principles in the same way. You never get the feel that you work in a mnc, you consider your self as a slave and yeah that's how they treat the employees here.

review_title: Honeywell is on of the best companies to work for.
pros:
Exposure to cutting-edge technology. 
Great management - They really care for their employee's.
Great oppurtunities to travel to various countries where Honeywell has an install base.
Hires diverse individuals.
Extensive libraries of training.
cons: Hard to get hired on.

pros:
- Decent salary for entry level/college graduates
- good health benefits
- generally safe environment, fairly clean/organized production areas
cons:
- Changes in education reimbursement policy (was 100%, is currently below 6,000 annual cap for graduate degree) makes the company less desirable to work for.  

- Other companies pay more

- All company picnics/charitable monetary matches/open houses cancelled.

- in current economy, management is focused on short term results affecting bottom line only (via outsourcing of internal work and supply base, contract push-out's, etc.)

- Management is not fostering healthy supplier relationships - actions being taken will cause future business with suppliers to suffer

- Performance reviews not taken seriously by all management - reviews and merits are based on a quota system.  Additionally, employees are not given proper access to resources, time, and training in order to meet specific goals.  Certain initiatives (relating to order policy, dock/reciepts scheduling, etc) actually make goals more difficult to achieve.  All employees have same goals (cut & paste template flowed down to all) in Performance Tracking system.  

- Honeywell corporate focuses on 40 hours mandatory training per year in their recruiting process.  However, Aerospace does not support employee development/training, especially in hard financial times or end-of-year timeframe.   The Six Sigma Certification is more a "degree mill" than learning process resulting in tangible process improvements.  Teams have been certified in less than 1 week when in actuality a Green Belt/Six Sigma project should takes several weeks.

- employee morale very low.  Management experiences high turnover in terms of people & initiatives/policies.  

- Increase in salary is based upon your relationship with management (who you know) & roles changes, not so much excelling in one's current position.  Most do not stay in a role more than 18 months (little personal or financial incentive to do so).  This results in little positive impact to the business - the employee learns the job and leaves for another job and bump in pay.

- extreme fear of layoffs as sourcing, production & support acitivity is phased out to low-cost regions abroad.

- Changes in health care policy to "encourage" voluntary retirement viewed as unethical by some emloyees further decreasing employee morale and loyality.

- Top executive bonuses do not match pay cuts inflicted upon employees actually performing the work which keeps parts moving & customers satisfied.

Medical benefits are very costly and not that great. Unlimited vacation policy is awkward and difficult to navigate.

job_title: Mechanical Design Engineer in Melville, NY
pros:
This job allowed me to develop my technical background as it provided me with all the necessary tools to learn and to improve as a professional. As many companies in the USA have already outsourced their operations and manufacturing, it is very hard to find jobs that can offer you technical on-hands development, except for Apple, Google, Samsung, and the big competitive ones... 
But, that was in the past as Honeywell current direction is to go to ODM and third party manufacturing nowadays...
cons:
There is no culture in this place. People do not have sense or urgency, no sense of ownership, no sense of belonging. No training offered: no courses in finance or in life, no nothing that can help you improve as a person. There are some sexual harassment in workplace and some adultery, where there are people sleeping with others. There are people who are aware of this too. There are people who drink alcohol in the job and do not get reprimanded. It seems there is no strong HR policies enforcement in place.   

There are people who have been here for 30+ years. They are slow and hard to deal with. They are not used to changes nor to adapt things to current situations. All they do is to let thing sit, whine, and perish. They always do things in a certain way. When new product was introduced they didn't know what to do and didn't want to think outside the box in figuring out other quality measurements and tests, but complained: "we used to do it in this way and what is wrong in doing it in the same way that we have been doing it for the past 20 years". Did you just hear what you just said?! The customer behavior changed, the product changed, if you test it in the same way as the past 20 years then your test result will fail! 

There are individuals that had been there for ~40 years or more, they don't do anything but to sleep on the job. When issue come, they hide inside a locked room and blames the factory for unfinished and not working setups. They intentionally come to work at 630am in the morning to pretend to work and so that nobody is at work and they don't have to work at all, and leave work at 230pm. This way the working time is the least possible overlapping with other people's working time. This is really smart. 

There are people that go to Mexico often, but don't know how to lean the process to deal with Mexico. Their suggestions conflict with the response from Mexico departments. They are unable to solve issues with regards to Mexico, unable to optimize the operations with Mexico, and are stuck with the same ECN process, and assume the process is fine and properly working. Another expired resource stuck in the times of the past... 

There are people who seem to only know how to manage toolings. They don't seem to be kind in learning other skills or other tasks. They are always walking around in the halls, would look at any excuse to have a long conversation. The conversation could last for 20-30 minutes about fishing. Instead of finding ways to resolve issues or help you to find solutions, they would rather chat until you forget what the issues were and walk away. Other people find excuses to not work and walk away as if nothing happened... 
 
The right hand does not know what the left hand is doing, and viceversa.  Whatever optimization a group is doing then it will definitely affect other groups and the same applies for other group. Groups are working in silo and there is no clear sense of direction as a company and no communication in between. Groups are not involved in design and there seems to be no management guidance in the company.

Sourcing in Mexico is a mess. They cannot do anything and they are mostly bound with agreements with vendors. They are non responsive. As they do not respond to your emails. They cannot get their job done properly. And someone from another team/division has to  fill in for their shoes and do their job properly. 

Mexico factory is a mess. They do not respond to your email. By the time they respond to your email the person that was in charge has already left the job. The turnover rate in Mexico is very big. There is always a new person in charge every two months. They are not responsive and not responsible. You get lots of headache dealing with them on a daily basis. 

There is no work from home policy. Or very few access to work from home. Guys, it is modern times, other companies are offering work from home policies because it improves work life balance. This division does not offer work from home to majority because they consider it as an additional expenses of $3/month per people. This is nothing compared to the boost in performance that you get from people. 

The laptops they provide are bulky and heavy. Not really portable. 

Coffee machines are old and obsolete. It takes them forever to warm water and they are noisy and slow. The coffee beans used taste bad and they don't change them for better one. It seems that they are lazy to improve the coffee beans or order the cheapest coffee beans. Some of them are nest of cockroaches, extra flavor for you!

Benefits keep on going down year by year. Honeywell health policy states to penalize people based on BMI. If your BMI is outside your range then you get penalized by $500. If your BMI does not improve but degrades with respect to last year's then you get penalized by additional $500. This policy shouldn't be legal, but apparently it is legal. Instead of penalizing the worker by such policies, it should encourage instead by providing games with fitbit and apple watches that give bonuses and activities to improve health like other companies are curretly doing. But, Honeywell chooses the negative action instead... Another benefit are the unwanted furlough that they provide you when the sales are down. I would prefer layoff than this so that you can inject new energy and new blood into the culture or to develop a culture, if there is one left... 

Honeywell implemented unlimited vacations starting 2018. But this is at the discretion of the manager. The policy is quote on quote "unlimited" to attract applicants, but in reality it is not widely implemented. Honeywell does not follow the honor system nor plan to implement such policy. However, this unlimited vacation is good for Honeywell in terms of layoffs and quitting because Honeywell no longer needs to compensate the extra time to their ex-workers. Do not think that an old conglomerate will be able to easily adapt to the current work policies. This company is old and will always be old to adapt to current times.  

There are many more issues in this division that I am not going to mention anymore because the list can get pretty long and I am tired of writing as well. There are lots of issues, lots of them... If you can choose NOT to work for this company, then please do so, I'd definitely recommend you to work at somewhere else that gives you better benefits and are better company than this one. It is NOT worth it to have Honeywell in your resume. The CONS are greater than the PROS... Take my advise for it!

Honeywell is too big and has too many divisions, too many products that sell at high  volume, and brand name. That's why this company can still survive with an internal mess. They do not care as little to some income keeps on pouring in. And when divisions do not work, then they sell it off or spin it off. Kudos to management!

pros: Uhhh, well if you're lucky enough to really not care about your job, you're easy going and can blend into the woodwork, you might be able to come in, keep your head down and just be left alone.
cons:
Anecdote: Upper management recognizes benefits of morale. Middle management then tasked with setting standard to measure morale - employees caring enough about the company to submit their own ideas for "continuous improvements" (CI's). Lower management is tasked with achieving measurable morale in the form of the volume of CI's - two a month. Bottom management puts a gun to each employee's head and tells them they'd better turn in 2 CI's a month or it'll go in their next performance review making them vulnerable the next time they have layoffs. Employees reluctantly turn in any CI's that'll give them two a month, including things like "found pen on floor, picked it up". Upper management sees numbers and thinks morale goals have been met, avalanche of mostly-worthless CI's waste several people's time, and employee morale couldn't be worse. This pretty much sums up everything Honeywell does.

Safety: Safety SEEMS to be a MAJOR concern for Honeywell! ... unless it's too inconvenient or expensive, then hell with ya. HSE's goal is not to keep the employees safe, but to reduce Honeywell's liability.

Pay: Rates have been frozen for well over a decade. After 8 years I was still making only 76% of the industry's standard for STARTING pay in the same job.

People: Most co-workers are hard-working and friendly people. Team Leads are too often unqualified simpletons with too much liability and not enough authority. Supervisors stay in their offices and don't want to be bothered with any of that work-related stuff. Upper management are usually polite but clueless. They set impossible standards based on BS numbers and the production floor creates more BS to look like they achieved it.

Advancement: None. Seriously, not a chance in hell.

I have never in my life worked for a company that has so perfectly represented the stereotypes of corporate bureaucracy. I don't know of anyone who works there that wants to, but they're the biggest employer in the area.

review_title: All in the name of Savings
pros: A strong legacy, a brand name that’s globally recognised, gain knowledge of legendary products in aerospace.
cons:
God. Where do I start? Since the new leadership has taken over, there has been a consistent effort to single handedly take ridiculous steps to curtail benefits and change policies all in the name of savings. They advertise about the company being ‘One Honeywell’ and there being nothing like HTS India or Honeywell International but the truth is that HTS India employees are now treated as these cheap cost animals that are available to grind. Their travel policies are extremely biased towards them. Your managers will ask you to travel for 28 days to US and the policy is such that you don’t get one rupee extra for having lived away from your family. The make reimbursements on actuals for up to 30 days. But then your on-site stakeholder says can you please extend your stay beyond 30 days. You extend and you’ll never get paid per diem because your original travel was planned for 30 days. It is disgusting. 

The new leadership feels they are tightening these policies and getting great margins but there’s been a steady talent drain from Honeywell and most managers will agree to this in private. This will eventually drive the innovation to ground. 
Recently they have started playing a new tune “THERE WILL BE RECESSION SO WE NEED TO BE READY” this is yet another effort to squeeze the employee benefits to drive cost savings. 

The work itself is structured in a way that most of your counterparts would be based on US. So everyday evening is work evening and you are expected to take calls and attend meetings. On being asked if all the work happens in evenings then whys that we still follow IST morning to evening times and why not have 1400HRS to 2300HRS shifts like rest of the US overlapping companies do and some other teams in Honeywell itself do, people were told that it was not required since everyone had laptops and they can work from home (note that internet is not paid for by company). It is obvious that this is to avoid additional shift allowance and transportation cost liability. This practice ensures that employee is in work mode from 800hrs in morning to 2300hrs in evening everyday. Call it an air conditioned sweatshop.

review_title: Honeywell Review for Philippines Shared Services for HR ADMIN LEARNING HELP HRS Services
pros:
Encourage to share best practices
Promotion, if and only "sipsip" you can be.
cons:
1. High attrition because of  Micromanaging, specially with team leaders. 

  A. You need to report every move. Where you are these and that.
B.  OT is big deal and are not encourage. Then add manpower as solution.

2. Politics - observable you can tell 1st to 2 weeks 
3.  ANNUAL SALARY INCREASE has poor explanation on Performance Score
they have this 9 block rating where at first may soundly fair because of behaviors and perfomance scores have been combined  but supervisors are very poor in explaining the corresponding rating. 

Safe answers and scripted as you can imagine how it can be like lines : 

"you can do better with your ratings if you do this and that but whenever being asked the basis are vague".

Interesting part is for the increase.
"..and this is the corresponding increase for your rating, we have a tool that recommends your increase" ( so where and how the 9block can be integrated if they have this tool, subjective isn't it?)

Tls are claiming reviews are back and forth.  Other companies would normally submit as it is that verification from the upper mgt.

3.  Lots of adhoc that do not contribute to individuals growth instead it adds on the pressure aside from the KPI you have.
Many unneccessary tasks. You need to MANUALLY PUNCH IN your meetings you can imagine that the management dont trust you. They say to this needs to be done measure the manpower needs but c'mon its been a year. Tls will remind you now and then, you shouldnt  forget to ENCODE your adhocs in the tracker.
 
Tips: Then, better if you purchase a time in motion tool to capture whatever your employees are doing. 

4.  Trainings - they promote people but do not have time to invest with the necessary skills  training set to impart those who've been promoted. At least an essential one, basics like 
1.  Leadership Development Programs
2.  People Management / People handling

For normal people like us, training are ONLY VISUAL boring.  No time for room trainings 

5. Office gossips - pioneers are the initiator and mock leadership team
